standard.name: CIS Controls Version 8
standard.description: The CIS Critical Security Controls are a prioritized set of actions to protect organizations and data from known cyber attack vectors.

controls.name: Establish and Maintain Detailed Enterprise Asset Inventory
controls.family: Inventory and Control of Enterprise Assets
controls.description: Establish and maintain an accurate, detailed, and up-to-date inventory of all enterprise assets with the potential to store or process data

article.section_name: Establish and Maintain Detailed Enterprise Asset Inventory
article.full_text: Establish and maintain an accurate, detailed, and up-to-date inventory of all enterprise assets with the potential to store or process data, to include: end-user devices (including portable and mobile), network devices, non-computing/IoT devices, and servers. Ensure the inventory records the network address (if static), hardware address, machine name, enterprise asset owner, department for each asset, and whether the asset has been approved to connect to the network. For mobile end-user devices, MDM type tools can support this process, where appropriate. This inventory includes assets connected to the infrastructure physically, virtually, remotely, and those within cloud environments. Additionally, it includes assets that are regularly connected to the enterprise's network infrastructure, even if they are not under control of the enterprise. Review and update the inventory of all enterprise assets bi-annually, or more frequently.
article.guidance: The first step in securing enterprise assets is knowing what needs to be secured. Creating and maintaining an accurate and up-to-date inventory is the foundation for an effective security program. Without knowing what assets exist, how can vulnerabilities be identified and remediated? Organizations should automate the process of maintaining an asset inventory wherever possible. Asset management tools, network discovery tools, and configuration management databases (CMDBs) can help maintain accurate inventories.

controls.name: Address Unauthorized Assets
controls.family: Inventory and Control of Enterprise Assets
controls.description: Ensure that only authorized assets are given access to the network

article.full_text: Ensure that a process exists to address unauthorized assets on a weekly, or more frequent, basis. The enterprise may choose to remove the asset from the network, deny the asset from connecting remotely to the network, or quarantine the asset.
article.guidance: Unauthorized assets represent a significant security risk as they are outside the control of the security team and may not have appropriate security controls applied. Automated network access control (NAC) solutions can help identify and remediate unauthorized assets. The response to unauthorized assets should be proportional to the risk they represent.

controls.name: Utilize an Active Discovery Tool
controls.family: Inventory and Control of Enterprise Assets
controls.description: Utilize an active discovery tool to identify assets connected to the enterprise's network

article.full_text: Utilize an active discovery tool to identify assets connected to the enterprise's network. Configure the active discovery tool to execute daily, or more frequently.
article.guidance: Passive network monitoring may not detect all assets, particularly those that communicate infrequently. Active discovery tools send queries to identify connected devices. These tools should be configured to run frequently enough to detect new assets quickly. Consider using multiple discovery methods for comprehensive coverage.

controls.name: Use Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) Logging
controls.family: Inventory and Control of Enterprise Assets
controls.description: Use DHCP logging on all DHCP servers to update the enterprise's asset inventory

article.section_name: Use Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) Logging
article.full_text: Use Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) logging on all DHCP servers or Internet Protocol (IP) address management tools to update the enterprise's asset inventory. Review and use logs to update the enterprise's asset inventory weekly, or more frequently.
article.guidance: DHCP logs provide valuable information about devices connecting to the network, including MAC addresses, hostnames, and timestamps. This data can help identify new or unauthorized devices. Automated correlation of DHCP logs with asset inventory can improve accuracy.

controls.name: Use a Passive Asset Discovery Tool
controls.family: Inventory and Control of Enterprise Assets
controls.description: Use a passive discovery tool to identify assets connected to the enterprise's network

article.section_name: Use a Passive Asset Discovery Tool
article.full_text: Use a passive discovery tool to identify assets connected to the enterprise's network. Review and use scans to update the enterprise's asset inventory at least weekly, or more frequently.
article.guidance: Passive discovery tools monitor network traffic to identify connected devices without actively querying them. This approach is less intrusive and can detect devices that might not respond to active scans. Combining passive and active discovery provides the most comprehensive visibility.

controls.name: Establish and Maintain a Software Inventory
controls.family: Inventory and Control of Software Assets
controls.description: Establish and maintain a detailed inventory of all licensed software installed on enterprise assets

article.section_name: Establish and Maintain a Software Inventory
article.full_text: Establish and maintain a detailed inventory of all licensed software installed on enterprise assets. The software inventory must document the title, publisher, initial install/use date, and business purpose for each entry; where appropriate, include the Uniform Resource Locator (URL), app store(s), version(s), deployment mechanism, and decommission date. Review and update the software inventory bi-annually, or more frequently.
article.guidance: A software inventory is essential for managing licenses, identifying vulnerabilities, and preventing unauthorized software. Automated software inventory tools can integrate with endpoint management systems to maintain accurate records. The inventory should distinguish between authorized and unauthorized software.

controls.name: Ensure Authorized Software is Currently Supported
controls.family: Inventory and Control of Software Assets
controls.description: Ensure that only currently supported software is designated as authorized

article.section_name: Ensure Authorized Software is Currently Supported
article.full_text: Ensure that only currently supported software is designated as authorized in the software inventory for enterprise assets. If software is unsupported, yet necessary for the fulfillment of the enterprise's mission, document an exception detailing mitigating controls and residual risk acceptance. For any unsupported software without an exception documentation, designate as unauthorized. Review the software list to verify software support at least monthly, or more frequently.
article.guidance: Unsupported software no longer receives security updates, making it a significant vulnerability. Organizations must track software lifecycles and plan migrations before support ends. Risk acceptance should be formal and include compensating controls.

controls.name: Address Unauthorized Software
controls.family: Inventory and Control of Software Assets
controls.description: Ensure that unauthorized software is either removed or the inventory is updated

article.full_text: Ensure that unauthorized software is either removed from use on enterprise assets or receives a documented exception. Review monthly, or more frequently.
article.guidance: Unauthorized software may introduce vulnerabilities, violate licensing agreements, or perform malicious activities. Automated tools can detect and remove unauthorized software. Exception processes should require business justification and security review.

controls.name: Utilize Automated Software Inventory Tools
controls.family: Inventory and Control of Software Assets
controls.description: Utilize software inventory tools throughout the enterprise

article.full_text: Utilize software inventory tools, when possible, throughout the enterprise to automate the documentation of all software on enterprise assets.
article.guidance: Manual software inventory is time-consuming and error-prone. Automated tools can continuously monitor installed software and report changes. These tools should integrate with asset management systems for centralized visibility.

controls.name: Allowlist Authorized Software
controls.family: Inventory and Control of Software Assets
controls.description: Use technical controls to ensure only authorized software can execute

article.full_text: Use technical controls, such as application allowlisting, to ensure that only authorized software can execute or be accessed. Reassess bi-annually, or more frequently.
article.guidance: Application allowlisting prevents unauthorized software from executing, providing strong protection against malware. Implementation should balance security with operational needs. Modern allowlisting solutions use multiple attributes (hash, certificate, path) for flexibility.

controls.name: Allowlist Authorized Libraries
controls.family: Inventory and Control of Software Assets
controls.description: Use technical controls to ensure only authorized software libraries can be loaded

article.full_text: Use technical controls, such as digital signatures and version control, to ensure that only authorized software libraries, such as specific .dll, .ocx, .so, etc., are allowed to load into a system process. Block unauthorized libraries from loading into a system process. Reassess bi-annually, or more frequently.
article.guidance: DLL hijacking and library injection are common attack vectors. Allowlisting authorized libraries prevents malicious code execution. This control complements application allowlisting for defense in depth.

controls.name: Allowlist Authorized Scripts
controls.family: Inventory and Control of Software Assets
controls.description: Use technical controls to ensure only authorized scripts can execute

article.full_text: Use technical controls, such as digital signatures and version control, to ensure that only authorized scripts, such as specific .ps1, .py, etc., are allowed to execute. Block unauthorized scripts from executing. Reassess bi-annually, or more frequently.
article.guidance: Scripts are frequently used by attackers due to their flexibility and prevalence. PowerShell, Python, and other scripting languages should be controlled. Consider script execution policies, digital signing requirements, and constrained language modes.

controls.name: Establish and Maintain a Data Management Process
controls.description: Establish and maintain a data management process

article.section_name: Establish and Maintain a Data Management Process
article.full_text: Establish and maintain a data management process. In the process, address data sensitivity, data owner, handling of data, data retention limits, and disposal requirements, based on sensitivity and retention standards for the enterprise. Review and update documentation annually, or when significant enterprise changes occur that could impact this Safeguard.
article.guidance: Understanding what data exists, where it resides, and how sensitive it is forms the foundation of data protection. The data management process should identify data owners, classify data, and establish handling requirements. Regular reviews ensure the process remains current.

controls.name: Establish and Maintain a Data Inventory
controls.description: Establish and maintain a data inventory based on the enterprise's data management process

article.section_name: Establish and Maintain a Data Inventory
article.full_text: Establish and maintain a data inventory, based on the enterprise's data management process. Inventory sensitive data, at a minimum. Review and update inventory annually, at a minimum, with a priority on sensitive data.
article.guidance: A data inventory documents what sensitive data exists, where it's stored, and who is responsible for it. This enables appropriate protection measures and supports compliance requirements. Data discovery tools can automate inventory creation and maintenance.

controls.name: Configure Data Access Control Lists
controls.description: Configure data access control lists based on a user's need to know

article.full_text: Configure data access control lists based on a user's need to know. Apply data access control lists, also known as access permissions, to local and remote file systems, databases, and applications.
article.guidance: The principle of least privilege should govern data access. Users should only access data necessary for their role. Regular access reviews ensure permissions remain appropriate. Automated tools can help manage and audit access controls.

controls.name: Enforce Data Retention
controls.description: Retain data according to the enterprise's data management process

article.full_text: Retain data according to the enterprise's data management process. Data retention must include both minimum and maximum timelines.
article.guidance: Data retention requirements balance legal/regulatory obligations with storage costs and security risks. Retaining data beyond necessity increases exposure. Automated retention policies ensure consistent application.

controls.name: Securely Dispose of Data
controls.description: Securely dispose of data as outlined in the enterprise's data management process

article.full_text: Securely dispose of data as outlined in the enterprise's data management process. Ensure the disposal process and method are commensurate with the data sensitivity.
article.guidance: Improper data disposal can lead to unauthorized disclosure. Disposal methods should match data sensitivity: secure deletion for digital data, shredding/incineration for physical media. Verify disposal is complete and irreversible.

controls.name: Encrypt Data on End-User Devices
controls.description: Encrypt data on end-user devices containing sensitive data

article.full_text: Encrypt data on end-user devices containing sensitive data. Example implementations can include: Windows BitLocker®, Apple FileVault®, Linux® dm-crypt.
article.guidance: Lost or stolen devices are a common data breach source. Full disk encryption protects data at rest, rendering it unreadable without proper authentication. Modern operating systems include built-in encryption capabilities.

controls.name: Establish and Maintain a Data Classification Scheme
controls.description: Establish and maintain an overall data classification scheme for the enterprise

article.section_name: Establish and Maintain a Data Classification Scheme
article.full_text: Establish and maintain an overall data classification scheme for the enterprise. Enterprises may use labels, such as "Sensitive," "Confidential," and "Public," and classify their data according to those labels. Review and update the classification scheme annually, or when significant enterprise changes occur that could impact this Safeguard.
article.guidance: Data classification provides a framework for applying appropriate security controls based on sensitivity. The scheme should be simple enough to use consistently but granular enough to differentiate protection needs. Train users on proper classification.

controls.name: Document Data Flows
controls.description: Document data flows for sensitive data

article.full_text: Document data flows. Data flow documentation includes service provider data flows and should be based on the enterprise's data management process. Review and update documentation annually, or when significant enterprise changes occur that could impact this Safeguard.
article.guidance: Understanding how data moves through systems helps identify security gaps and compliance requirements. Data flow diagrams should show collection points, processing locations, storage systems, and transmission paths. This is essential for privacy impact assessments.

controls.name: Encrypt Data on Removable Media
controls.description: Encrypt data on removable media

article.full_text: Encrypt data on removable media.
article.guidance: Removable media (USB drives, external hard drives) are easily lost or stolen. Encryption protects data if media falls into wrong hands. Consider restricting removable media use through technical controls where appropriate.

controls.name: Encrypt Sensitive Data in Transit
controls.description: Encrypt sensitive data in transit

article.full_text: Encrypt sensitive data in transit. Example implementations can include: Transport Layer Security (TLS) and Open Secure Shell (OpenSSH).
article.guidance: Network traffic can be intercepted, exposing sensitive data. Encryption protects data during transmission. Use strong, current protocols (TLS 1.2+) and disable weak ciphers. Implement certificate validation to prevent man-in-the-middle attacks.

controls.name: Encrypt Sensitive Data at Rest
controls.description: Encrypt sensitive data at rest on servers, applications, and databases

article.full_text: Encrypt sensitive data at rest on servers, applications, and databases containing sensitive data. Storage-layer encryption, also known as server-side encryption, meets the minimum requirement of this Safeguard. Additional encryption methods may include application-layer encryption, also known as client-side encryption, where access to the data storage device(s) does not permit access to the plain-text data.
article.guidance: Database and filesystem encryption protect data if physical media is stolen or improperly disposed. Key management is critical - keys must be protected and rotated regularly. Consider encryption performance impact on high-volume systems.

controls.name: Segment Data Processing and Storage
controls.description: Segment data processing and storage based on the sensitivity of the data

article.full_text: Segment data processing and storage based on the sensitivity of the data. Do not process sensitive data on enterprise assets intended for lower sensitivity data.
article.guidance: Network segmentation limits the impact of a breach. Sensitive data should be isolated on separate systems with stricter controls. This reduces the attack surface and simplifies compliance. Use firewalls, VLANs, and access controls to enforce segmentation.

controls.name: Deploy a Data Loss Prevention Solution
controls.description: Deploy an automated tool to prevent sensitive data exfiltration

article.section_name: Deploy a Data Loss Prevention Solution
article.full_text: Deploy an automated tool, such as a host-based Data Loss Prevention (DLP) tool to identify all sensitive data stored, processed, or transmitted through enterprise assets, including those located onsite or at a remote service provider, and update the enterprise's sensitive data inventory.
article.guidance: DLP tools monitor data in motion, at rest, and in use to prevent unauthorized disclosure. Effective DLP requires accurate data classification and well-defined policies. Start with monitoring mode before enforcement to tune policies.

controls.name: Log Sensitive Data Access
controls.description: Log sensitive data access including modification and disposal

article.full_text: Log sensitive data access, including modification and disposal.
article.guidance: Logging sensitive data access enables detection of unauthorized access and supports forensic investigations. Logs should capture who accessed what data, when, and from where. Protect logs from tampering and retain according to policy.

controls.name: Establish and Maintain a Secure Configuration Process
controls.family: Secure Configuration of Enterprise Assets and Software
controls.description: Establish and maintain a secure configuration process for enterprise assets

article.section_name: Establish and Maintain a Secure Configuration Process
article.full_text: Establish and maintain a secure configuration process for enterprise assets (end-user devices, including portable and mobile, non-computing/IoT devices, and servers) and software (operating systems and applications). Review and update documentation annually, or when significant enterprise changes occur that could impact this Safeguard.
article.guidance: Default configurations are rarely secure. A documented secure configuration process ensures consistent security across assets. The process should define baseline configurations, change procedures, and exception handling. Use industry benchmarks (CIS Benchmarks, DISA STIGs) as starting points.

controls.name: Establish and Maintain a Secure Configuration Process for Network Infrastructure
controls.family: Secure Configuration of Enterprise Assets and Software
controls.description: Establish and maintain a secure configuration process for network devices

article.section_name: Establish and Maintain a Secure Configuration Process for Network Infrastructure
article.full_text: Establish and maintain a secure configuration process for network infrastructure. Review and update documentation annually, or when significant enterprise changes occur that could impact this Safeguard.
article.guidance: Network devices (routers, switches, firewalls) require hardening. Disable unnecessary services, change default credentials, enable logging, and restrict management access. Maintain configuration backups and use configuration management tools.

controls.name: Configure Automatic Session Locking
controls.family: Secure Configuration of Enterprise Assets and Software
controls.description: Configure automatic session locking on enterprise assets after inactivity

article.full_text: Configure automatic session locking on enterprise assets after a defined period of inactivity. For general purpose operating systems, the period must not exceed 15 minutes. For mobile end-user devices, the period must not exceed 2 minutes.
article.guidance: Unattended sessions are vulnerable to unauthorized access. Automatic locking mitigates this risk. Shorter timeouts provide better security but may impact user productivity - balance based on environment sensitivity.

controls.name: Implement and Manage a Firewall
controls.family: Secure Configuration of Enterprise Assets and Software
controls.description: Implement and manage a firewall on end-user devices

article.section_name: Implement and Manage a Firewall on Servers
article.full_text: Implement and manage a firewall on servers, where supported. Example implementations include a virtual firewall, operating system firewall, or a third-party firewall agent.
article.guidance: Host-based firewalls provide defense in depth by filtering traffic at the endpoint. Configure firewalls to deny by default and only allow necessary connections. Centralized management ensures consistent policies across the enterprise.

controls.name: Implement and Manage a Firewall on End-User Devices
controls.family: Secure Configuration of Enterprise Assets and Software
controls.description: Implement and manage a firewall on end-user devices

article.section_name: Implement and Manage a Firewall on End-User Devices
article.full_text: Implement and manage a host-based firewall or port-filtering tool on end-user devices, with a default-deny rule that drops all traffic except those services and ports that are explicitly allowed.
article.guidance: End-user device firewalls protect against network-based attacks and lateral movement. Enable firewalls by default and prevent users from disabling them. Regular audits ensure firewalls remain enabled and properly configured.

controls.name: Securely Manage Enterprise Assets and Software
controls.family: Secure Configuration of Enterprise Assets and Software
controls.description: Securely manage enterprise assets and software

article.section_name: Securely Manage Enterprise Assets and Software
article.full_text: Securely manage enterprise assets and software. Example implementations include managing configuration through version-controlled-infrastructure-as-code and accessing administrative interfaces over secure network protocols, such as Secure Shell (SSH) and Hypertext Transfer Protocol Secure (HTTPS). Do not use insecure management protocols, such as Telnet (Teletype Network) and HTTP, unless operationally essential.
article.guidance: Management interfaces are high-value targets. Protect them with secure protocols, strong authentication, and network segmentation. Infrastructure-as-code enables consistent, auditable configuration management. Eliminate insecure protocols wherever possible.

controls.name: Manage Default Accounts
controls.family: Secure Configuration of Enterprise Assets and Software
controls.description: Manage default accounts on enterprise assets and software

article.section_name: Manage Default Accounts on Enterprise Assets and Software
article.full_text: Manage default accounts on enterprise assets and software, such as root, administrator, and other pre-configured vendor accounts. Example implementations can include: disabling default accounts or making them unusable.
article.guidance: Default accounts with well-known credentials are frequently exploited. Disable, rename, or change passwords for all default accounts. Audit systems regularly to detect new default accounts introduced by software installations or updates.

controls.name: Uninstall or Disable Unnecessary Services
controls.family: Secure Configuration of Enterprise Assets and Software
controls.description: Uninstall or disable unnecessary services on enterprise assets and software

article.section_name: Uninstall or Disable Unnecessary Services on Enterprise Assets and Software
article.full_text: Uninstall or disable unnecessary services on enterprise assets and software, such as an unused file sharing service, web application module, or service function.
article.guidance: Every enabled service increases the attack surface. Disable services not required for business function. Regular reviews identify services that become unnecessary over time. Use minimum viable deployment principles.

controls.name: Configure Trusted DNS Servers
controls.family: Secure Configuration of Enterprise Assets and Software
controls.description: Configure trusted DNS servers on enterprise assets

article.section_name: Configure Trusted DNS Servers on Enterprise Assets
article.full_text: Configure trusted DNS servers on enterprise assets. Example implementations include: configuring assets to use enterprise-controlled DNS servers and/or reputable externally accessible DNS servers.
article.guidance: DNS is critical infrastructure that can be attacked to redirect traffic or exfiltrate data. Use trusted, secure DNS servers. Consider DNS filtering services to block malicious domains. Implement DNSSEC where possible.

controls.name: Enforce Automatic Device Lockout
controls.family: Secure Configuration of Enterprise Assets and Software
controls.description: Enforce automatic device lockout following failed authentication attempts

article.section_name: Enforce Automatic Device Lockout on Portable End-User Devices
article.full_text: Enforce automatic device lockout following a predetermined threshold of local failed authentication attempts on portable end-user devices, where supported. For laptops, the lockout must occur after no more than five (5) failed login attempts. For tablets and smartphones, the lockout must occur after no more than ten (10) failed login attempts. Mobile Device Management (MDM) is the recommended solution to enforce device lockouts on mobile end-user devices.
article.guidance: Failed login lockout protects against brute force attacks. Balance security with usability - too strict may cause operational issues. Implement account unlocking procedures that verify identity. Track lockout events for anomaly detection.

controls.name: Enforce Remote Wipe Capability
controls.family: Secure Configuration of Enterprise Assets and Software
controls.description: Enforce remote wipe capability on portable devices

article.section_name: Enforce Remote Wipe Capability on Portable End-User Devices
article.full_text: Remotely wipe enterprise data from enterprise-owned portable end-user devices when deemed appropriate such as: lost or stolen devices, devices that are out of compliance with security policies, or devices that are being retired. Mobile Device Management (MDM) tools include the capability to remotely wipe devices.
article.guidance: Lost or stolen mobile devices pose significant data breach risk. Remote wipe capabilities enable rapid response. Test wipe functionality regularly. Consider selective wipe to preserve personal data on BYOD devices.

controls.name: Separate Enterprise Workspaces
controls.family: Secure Configuration of Enterprise Assets and Software
controls.description: Separate enterprise workspace from personal workspaces on mobile devices

article.section_name: Separate Enterprise Workspaces on Mobile End-User Devices
article.full_text: Ensure separate enterprise workspaces are used on mobile end-user devices, where supported. Example implementations include: using an Apple® managed Apple ID, Android™ Work Profile, or Microsoft® Intune App Protection Policies. Managed Apple ID is also utilized by mobile devices managed directly through an MDM, where an Apple® Business Manager account has been associated with an enterprise.
article.guidance: BYOD creates challenges separating corporate and personal data. Containerization technologies create secure workspaces for enterprise data while respecting privacy. This enables selective wipe of only corporate data.

controls.name: Establish and Maintain an Inventory of Accounts
controls.description: Establish and maintain an inventory of all accounts managed in the enterprise

article.section_name: Establish and Maintain an Inventory of Accounts
article.full_text: Establish and maintain an inventory of all accounts managed in the enterprise. The inventory must include both user and administrator accounts. The inventory, at a minimum, should contain the person's name, username, start date, and end date. Review the inventory quarterly, or more frequently.
article.guidance: Account inventory enables identity governance and access management. Track account lifecycle from creation to deletion. Regular reviews identify orphaned accounts from terminated employees. Automated IAM systems can maintain dynamic inventories.

controls.name: Use Unique Passwords
controls.description: Use unique passwords for all enterprise assets

article.full_text: Use unique passwords for all enterprise assets. Best practice implementation includes, at a minimum, an 8-character password for accounts using MFA and a 14-character password for accounts not using MFA.
article.guidance: Password reuse enables credential stuffing attacks. Unique passwords limit breach impact to individual accounts. Password managers facilitate unique password use. Length is more important than complexity for password strength.

controls.name: Disable Dormant Accounts
controls.description: Delete or disable dormant accounts after 45 days of inactivity

article.full_text: Delete or disable any dormant accounts after a period of 45 days of inactivity, where supported.
article.guidance: Dormant accounts are attractive targets as compromise may go unnoticed. Automated processes should flag inactive accounts for review. Consider temporary suspension before permanent deletion. Document exceptions for seasonal workers.

controls.name: Restrict Administrator Privileges to Dedicated Accounts
controls.description: Restrict administrator privileges to dedicated administrator accounts

article.section_name: Restrict Administrator Privileges to Dedicated Administrator Accounts
article.full_text: Restrict administrator privileges to dedicated administrator accounts on enterprise assets. Conduct general computing activities, such as internet browsing, email, and productivity suite use, from the user's primary, non-privileged account.
article.guidance: Using administrative accounts for routine tasks increases risk. Attackers targeting administrators gain elevated access. Separate accounts for administrative duties limit exposure. Privileged access management (PAM) solutions enforce this separation.

controls.name: Establish and Maintain an Inventory of Service Accounts
controls.description: Establish and maintain an inventory of service accounts

article.section_name: Establish and Maintain an Inventory of Service Accounts
article.full_text: Establish and maintain an inventory of service accounts. The inventory, at a minimum, must contain department owner, review date, and purpose. Perform service account reviews to validate that all active accounts are authorized, on a recurring schedule at a minimum quarterly, or more frequently.
article.guidance: Service accounts often have broad privileges and weak password policies. Maintaining an inventory ensures accountability. Regular reviews identify unused or excessive privileges. Consider managed service identities where possible.

controls.name: Centralize Account Management
controls.description: Centralize account management through directory services

article.full_text: Centralize account management through a directory or identity service.
article.guidance: Centralized identity management enables consistent access control, simplifies administration, and provides centralized audit trails. Directory services (AD, LDAP, cloud identity providers) should be the authoritative source. Integrate applications via SSO where possible.

controls.name: Establish an Access Granting Process
controls.description: Establish and follow a process for granting access to enterprise assets

article.full_text: Establish and follow a process, preferably automated, for granting access to enterprise assets upon new hire, rights grant, or role change of a user.
article.guidance: Formal access provisioning ensures appropriate access based on role. Automated workflows improve speed and consistency while maintaining audit trails. Access should be granted based on principle of least privilege and approved by asset owners.

controls.name: Establish an Access Revoking Process
controls.description: Establish and follow a process for revoking access to enterprise assets

article.full_text: Establish and follow a process, preferably automated, for revoking access to enterprise assets, through disabling accounts immediately upon termination, rights revocation, or role change of a user. Disabling accounts, instead of deleting accounts, may be necessary to preserve audit trails.
article.guidance: Prompt access revocation upon termination is critical security. Automated deprovisioning triggered by HR systems ensures timely execution. Disable rather than delete to maintain audit trails. Immediately revoke remote access and administrative privileges.

controls.name: Require MFA for Externally-Exposed Applications
controls.description: Require multi-factor authentication for all externally-exposed enterprise applications

article.full_text: Require all externally-exposed enterprise or third-party applications to enforce MFA, where supported. Enforcing MFA through a directory service or SSO provider is a satisfactory implementation of this Safeguard.
article.guidance: Internet-facing applications are constant attack targets. MFA significantly reduces credential compromise risk. Phishing-resistant MFA (hardware tokens, biometrics) provides stronger protection than SMS-based codes. Plan for MFA reset procedures.

controls.name: Require MFA for Remote Network Access
controls.description: Require multi-factor authentication for all remote network access

article.section_name: Require MFA for Remote Network Access
article.full_text: Require MFA for remote network access.
article.guidance: VPN and remote access are frequent attack vectors. MFA prevents unauthorized access from stolen credentials. Consider risk-based authentication that adjusts requirements based on location, device, and behavior patterns.

controls.name: Require MFA for Administrative Access
controls.description: Require multi-factor authentication for all administrative access accounts

article.full_text: Require MFA for all administrative access accounts, where supported, on all enterprise assets, whether managed on-site or through a third-party provider.
article.guidance: Administrative accounts are high-value targets. MFA is essential for protecting privileged access. Use phishing-resistant MFA for administrators. PAM solutions can enforce MFA for administrative sessions.

controls.name: Establish and Maintain an Inventory of Authentication Systems
controls.description: Establish and maintain an inventory of authentication systems

article.section_name: Establish and Maintain an Inventory of Authentication and Authorization Systems
article.full_text: Establish and maintain an inventory of the enterprise's authentication and authorization systems, including those hosted on-site or at a third-party provider. Review and update the inventory, at a minimum, annually, or more frequently.
article.guidance: Multiple authentication systems increase complexity and security gaps. Inventory helps consolidate and standardize. Document integration points, supported protocols, and dependencies. Work toward centralized identity management.

controls.name: Centralize Access Control
controls.description: Centralize access control for all enterprise assets

article.full_text: Centralize access control for all enterprise assets through a directory service or SSO provider, where supported.
article.guidance: Centralized access control simplifies management and improves security visibility. SSO reduces password fatigue while enabling centralized policies. Implement with strong MFA and monitor for anomalous access patterns.

controls.name: Define and Maintain Role-Based Access Control
controls.description: Define and maintain role-based access control

article.section_name: Define and Maintain Role-Based Access Control
article.full_text: Define and maintain role-based access control, through determining and documenting the access rights necessary for each role within the enterprise to successfully carry out its assigned duties. Perform access control reviews of enterprise assets to validate that all privileges are authorized, on a recurring schedule at a minimum annually, or more frequently.
article.guidance: RBAC simplifies access management by granting permissions based on job functions rather than individuals. Document standard roles and their permissions. Regular reviews ensure roles remain appropriate as job functions evolve. Avoid role explosion through careful design.

controls.name: Establish and Maintain a Vulnerability Management Process
controls.description: Establish and maintain a vulnerability management process

article.section_name: Establish and Maintain a Vulnerability Management Process
article.full_text: Establish and maintain a documented vulnerability management process for enterprise assets. Review and update documentation annually, or when significant enterprise changes occur that could impact this Safeguard.
article.guidance: Systematic vulnerability management is essential for maintaining security posture. The process should define roles, scanning frequency, prioritization criteria, and remediation timeframes. Integrate with change management and asset inventory.

controls.name: Establish and Maintain a Remediation Process
controls.description: Establish and maintain a remediation process

article.section_name: Establish and Maintain a Remediation Process
article.full_text: Establish and maintain a risk-based remediation strategy documented in a remediation process, with monthly, or more frequent, reviews.
article.guidance: Not all vulnerabilities pose equal risk. Risk-based remediation prioritizes based on exploitability, business impact, and threat intelligence. Define SLAs for different severity levels. Track remediation metrics to measure program effectiveness.

controls.name: Perform Automated Vulnerability Scans
controls.description: Perform automated vulnerability scans of internal enterprise assets

article.section_name: Perform Automated Operating System Patch Management
article.full_text: Perform automated operating system patch management on enterprise assets on a monthly, or more frequent, basis.
article.guidance: Operating system vulnerabilities are frequently exploited. Automated patch management ensures timely deployment. Test patches in non-production before widespread deployment. Emergency patching procedures should exist for critical vulnerabilities.

controls.name: Perform Automated Application Patch Management
controls.description: Perform automated application patch management

article.full_text: Perform automated application patch management on a monthly, or more frequent, basis.
article.guidance: Applications introduce vulnerabilities distinct from OS patches. Many applications lack auto-update capabilities. Third-party patch management tools can help. Prioritize internet-facing and high-risk applications.

controls.name: Perform Automated Vulnerability Scans
controls.description: Perform automated vulnerability scans of internal systems

article.section_name: Perform Automated Vulnerability Scans of Internal Enterprise Assets
article.full_text: Perform automated vulnerability scans of internal enterprise assets on a quarterly, or more frequent, basis. Conduct both authenticated and unauthenticated scans, using a SCAP-compliant vulnerability scanning tool.
article.guidance: Regular vulnerability scanning identifies security weaknesses before attackers exploit them. Authenticated scans provide deeper visibility. SCAP compliance ensures standardized reporting. Continuous scanning provides better coverage than periodic scans.

controls.name: Perform Automated Vulnerability Scans of Externally-Exposed Assets
controls.description: Perform automated vulnerability scans of externally-exposed enterprise assets

article.section_name: Perform Automated Vulnerability Scans of Externally-Exposed Enterprise Assets
article.full_text: Perform automated vulnerability scans of externally-exposed enterprise assets using a SCAP-compliant vulnerability scanning tool. Perform scans on a monthly, or more frequent, basis.
article.guidance: External assets face constant attack. More frequent scanning of internet-facing systems is warranted. Consider continuous external monitoring services. Coordinate scans to avoid triggering security controls or affecting availability.

controls.name: Remediate Detected Vulnerabilities
controls.description: Remediate detected vulnerabilities in software within timeframes based on risk

article.full_text: Remediate detected vulnerabilities in software through processes and tooling on a monthly, or more frequent, basis, based on the remediation process.
article.guidance: Vulnerability discovery is meaningless without remediation. Track time-to-remediate metrics. When patches aren't available, implement compensating controls. Vulnerability management tools should integrate with ticketing systems for workflow.

controls.name: Establish and Maintain an Audit Log Management Process
controls.description: Establish and maintain an audit log management process

article.section_name: Establish and Maintain an Audit Log Management Process
article.full_text: Establish and maintain an audit log management process that defines the enterprise's logging requirements. At a minimum, address the collection, review, and retention of audit logs for enterprise assets. Review and update documentation annually, or when significant enterprise changes occur that could impact this Safeguard.
article.guidance: Logs provide evidence of security events and support incident investigation. The log management process should define what to log, retention periods, review procedures, and protection measures. Consider regulatory requirements when setting retention policies.

controls.name: Collect Audit Logs
controls.description: Collect audit logs from enterprise assets

article.full_text: Collect audit logs. Ensure that logging, per the enterprise's audit log management process, has been enabled across enterprise assets.
article.guidance: Comprehensive logging is foundational for security monitoring. Enable logging on operating systems, applications, network devices, and security tools. Ensure time synchronization for accurate correlation. Monitor for logging failures.

controls.name: Ensure Adequate Audit Log Storage
controls.description: Ensure adequate storage for all collected audit logs

article.full_text: Ensure that logging destinations maintain adequate storage to comply with the enterprise's audit log management process.
article.guidance: Insufficient storage causes log loss, creating security blind spots. Monitor storage capacity and plan for growth. Consider tiered storage: hot storage for recent logs, cold storage for archives. Compression can extend capacity.

controls.name: Standardize Time Synchronization
controls.description: Standardize time synchronization across all enterprise assets

article.full_text: Standardize time synchronization. Configure enterprise assets to synchronize time with an authenticated and designated time source to ensure that any discrepancies can be corrected.
article.guidance: Accurate timestamps are critical for log correlation and forensics. Use NTP with authenticated time sources. Monitor for time drift. Maintain redundant time sources for reliability. Document timezone handling in log management.

controls.name: Collect Detailed Audit Logs
controls.description: Collect detailed audit logs with all relevant information

article.full_text: Configure detailed audit logging for enterprise assets containing sensitive data. Include event source, date, username, timestamp, source addresses, destination addresses, and other useful elements that could assist in a forensic investigation.
article.guidance: Detailed logs support effective investigation. Log verbosity should balance detail with storage/performance. Focus detailed logging on high-value assets and sensitive data. Ensure personally identifiable information in logs is handled appropriately.

controls.name: Collect DNS Query Audit Logs
controls.description: Collect DNS query audit logs

article.full_text: Collect DNS query audit logs on enterprise assets, where appropriate and supported.
article.guidance: DNS queries reveal communication patterns and can indicate malicious activity (C2 communications, data exfiltration, malware). DNS logging should capture query, response, source, and timestamp. Consider privacy implications of DNS logging.

controls.name: Collect URL Request Audit Logs
controls.description: Collect URL request audit logs

article.full_text: Collect URL request audit logs on enterprise assets, where appropriate and supported.
article.guidance: URL logs help identify malicious sites, policy violations, and data exfiltration. Web proxies and secure web gateways provide this capability. Balance security visibility with user privacy. Consider SSL/TLS inspection for encrypted traffic.

controls.name: Collect Command-Line Audit Logs
controls.description: Collect command-line audit logs

article.full_text: Collect command-line audit logs. Example implementations include collecting audit logs from PowerShell®, BASH™, and remote administrative terminals.
article.guidance: Command-line activity reveals attacker actions and insider threats. PowerShell, Bash, and other shells should have enhanced logging enabled. Be mindful of sensitive data in command parameters. Consider obfuscating passwords in logs.

controls.name: Centralize Audit Logs
controls.description: Centralize audit log collection and retention

article.full_text: Centralize, to the extent possible, audit log collection and retention across enterprise assets.
article.guidance: Centralized logging enables efficient analysis, correlation, and long-term retention. SIEM or log management systems aggregate logs from multiple sources. Protect log infrastructure as it contains sensitive information. Ensure secure log transmission.

controls.name: Retain Audit Logs
controls.description: Retain audit logs for appropriate time periods

article.full_text: Retain audit logs across enterprise assets for a minimum of 90 days.
article.guidance: Retention periods should support incident investigation while considering storage costs and regulatory requirements. Longer retention may be required for compliance. Archive old logs to cold storage. Protect archived logs from tampering.

controls.name: Conduct Audit Log Reviews
controls.description: Conduct reviews of audit logs to detect anomalies

article.full_text: Conduct reviews of audit logs to detect anomalies or abnormal events that could indicate a potential threat. Conduct reviews on a weekly, or more frequent, basis.
article.guidance: Logs are worthless without analysis. Regular reviews identify suspicious activity. SIEM tools automate analysis using correlation rules and anomaly detection. Focus reviews on high-value assets and known attack patterns. Document findings.

controls.name: Collect Service Provider Logs
controls.description: Collect service provider logs

article.full_text: Collect service provider logs, where supported. Example implementations include collecting authentication and authorization events, data creation and disposal events, and user management events.
article.guidance: Cloud and SaaS provider logs are essential for comprehensive visibility. API access may be required to collect logs. Integrate provider logs into central log management. Understand provider retention policies and export logs as needed.

controls.name: Ensure Use of Only Fully Supported Browsers and Email Clients
controls.description: Ensure only fully supported browsers and email clients are allowed

article.section_name: Ensure Use of Only Fully Supported Browsers and Email Clients
article.full_text: Ensure only fully supported browsers and email clients are allowed to execute in the enterprise, only using the latest version of browsers and email clients provided through the vendor.
article.guidance: Browsers and email clients are common attack vectors. Unsupported versions contain known vulnerabilities. Automated tools can enforce supported versions. Consider enterprise browser management solutions for centralized control and updates.

controls.name: Use DNS Filtering Services
controls.description: Use DNS filtering services to block access to known malicious domains

article.full_text: Use DNS filtering services on all enterprise assets to block access to known malicious domains.
article.guidance: DNS filtering prevents connections to malicious sites before they occur. Services provide regularly updated threat intelligence. Can block phishing, malware, and C2 traffic. Works across all applications using DNS. Consider redundant DNS filtering for reliability.

controls.name: Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters
controls.description: Enforce URL filtering to limit website access

article.section_name: Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters
article.full_text: Enforce and update network-based URL filters to limit an enterprise asset from connecting to potentially malicious or unapproved websites. Example implementations include category-based filtering, reputation-based filtering, or through the use of block lists. Enforce filters for all enterprise assets.
article.guidance: URL filtering extends beyond DNS to block access by category or reputation. Web proxies and secure web gateways provide this capability. Policies should balance security with productivity. Regular review and updating of filter policies is essential.

controls.name: Restrict Unnecessary or Unauthorized Browser and Email Client Extensions
controls.description: Restrict browser and email client extensions

article.section_name: Restrict Unnecessary or Unauthorized Browser and Email Client Extensions
article.full_text: Restrict, either through uninstalling or disabling, any unauthorized or unnecessary browser or email client plugins, extensions, and add-on applications.
article.guidance: Extensions can access sensitive data and introduce vulnerabilities. Maintain allowlist of approved extensions. Enterprise browser management can enforce extension policies. Review extensions for excessive permissions. Consider browser isolation for high-risk browsing.

controls.name: Implement DMARC
controls.description: Implement DMARC policy to protect against email spoofing

article.full_text: To lower the chance of spoofed or modified emails from valid domains, implement DMARC policy and verification, starting with implementing the Sender Policy Framework (SPF) and the DomainKeys Identified Mail (DKIM) standards.
article.guidance: DMARC protects against email spoofing and phishing. Start with monitoring mode (p=none), then progress to quarantine or reject policies. SPF and DKIM must be properly configured first. Monitor DMARC reports to identify legitimate vs. malicious email sources.

controls.name: Block Unnecessary File Types
controls.description: Block unnecessary file types from email

article.full_text: Block unnecessary file types attempting to enter the enterprise's email gateway.
article.guidance: Many file types are rarely legitimate business email attachments but commonly used for malware (e.g., .exe, .scr, .vbs). Email gateways can block or quarantine these. Document exceptions with justification. Consider blocking by MIME type, not just extension.

controls.name: Deploy and Maintain Email Server Anti-Malware Protections
controls.description: Deploy anti-malware on email servers

article.section_name: Deploy and Maintain Email Server Anti-Malware Protections
article.full_text: Deploy and maintain email server anti-malware protections, such as attachment scanning and/or sandboxing.
article.guidance: Email is a primary malware delivery mechanism. Multi-layer scanning (gateway, server, endpoint) provides defense in depth. Sandboxing detonates suspicious attachments in isolated environments. Keep signatures and detection engines updated.

controls.name: Deploy and Maintain Anti-Malware Software
controls.description: Deploy anti-malware software on all enterprise assets

article.full_text: Deploy and maintain anti-malware software on all enterprise assets.
article.guidance: Anti-malware is fundamental security control. Should be deployed on endpoints, servers, and network devices where supported. Centralized management ensures consistent deployment and configuration. Next-generation solutions use behavior-based detection beyond signatures.

controls.name: Configure Automatic Anti-Malware Signature Updates
controls.description: Configure automatic signature updates for anti-malware

article.full_text: Configure automatic updates for anti-malware signature files on all enterprise assets.
article.guidance: Outdated signatures cannot detect new threats. Automatic updates ensure timely protection. Configure updates to occur multiple times daily. Monitor update success. For air-gapped systems, establish manual update procedures. Consider cloud-delivered protection for real-time updates.

controls.name: Disable Autorun and Autoplay for Removable Media
controls.description: Disable autorun/autoplay for removable media

article.section_name: Disable Autorun and Autoplay for Removable Media
article.full_text: Disable autorun and autoplay auto-execute functionality for removable media.
article.guidance: Autorun/autoplay can automatically execute malware from USB drives and other removable media. Disabling prevents automatic malware execution. Configure through Group Policy or endpoint management. Consider blocking removable media entirely for high-security environments.

controls.name: Configure Automatic Anti-Malware Scanning
controls.description: Configure automatic anti-malware scanning

article.full_text: Configure anti-malware software to automatically scan removable media.
article.guidance: Real-time scanning detects malware upon access. Schedule regular full system scans. Balance scan frequency with performance impact. Configure scanning of email attachments, downloads, and file shares. Ensure scans include compressed and archived files.

controls.name: Enable Anti-Exploitation Features
controls.description: Enable anti-exploitation features on enterprise assets

article.full_text: Enable anti-exploitation features on enterprise assets and software, where possible, such as Microsoft® Data Execution Prevention (DEP), Windows® Defender Exploit Guard (WDEG), or Apple® System Integrity Protection (SIP) and Gatekeeper™.
article.guidance: Anti-exploitation features prevent exploit techniques (DEP, ASLR, control flow guard). Modern operating systems include these protections. Ensure they're enabled and not disabled for compatibility. Third-party solutions provide additional protection. Test application compatibility.

controls.name: Centrally Manage Anti-Malware Software
controls.description: Centrally manage anti-malware software

article.full_text: Use a centrally managed anti-malware software to continuously monitor and defend each of the enterprise's workstations and servers.
article.guidance: Central management ensures consistent policies, monitoring, and reporting. Prevents users from disabling protection. Provides visibility into malware detections across the enterprise. Enables rapid response to new threats. Supports compliance reporting.

controls.name: Use Behavior-Based Anti-Malware Software
controls.description: Use behavior-based anti-malware

article.full_text: Use behavior-based anti-malware software.
article.guidance: Signature-based detection cannot catch zero-day malware. Behavior-based detection identifies malicious activities regardless of signature. Machine learning and AI enhance detection. EDR solutions provide advanced behavior monitoring. Balance detection sensitivity with false positives.

controls.name: Establish and Maintain a Data Recovery Process
controls.description: Establish data recovery processes

article.section_name: Establish and Maintain a Data Recovery Process
article.full_text: Establish and maintain a data recovery process. In the process, address the scope of data recovery activities, recovery prioritization, and the security of backup data. Review and update documentation annually, or when significant enterprise changes occur that could impact this Safeguard.
article.guidance: Data recovery is critical for business continuity and ransomware recovery. Document RTO and RPO for each system. Define backup scope including systems, applications, and data. Address backup security (encryption, access controls). Test recovery procedures regularly.

controls.name: Perform Automated Backups
controls.description: Perform automated backups of critical data

article.full_text: Perform automated backups of in-scope enterprise assets. Run backups weekly, or more frequently, based on the sensitivity of the data.
article.guidance: Manual backups are unreliable. Automation ensures consistent backup execution. Frequency should match data change rate and RPO. Consider continuous data protection for critical systems. Implement 3-2-1 backup strategy (3 copies, 2 media types, 1 offsite).

controls.name: Protect Recovery Data
controls.description: Protect backup and recovery data

article.full_text: Protect recovery data with equivalent controls to the original data. Reference encryption or data separation, based on requirements.
article.guidance: Backups contain sensitive data requiring protection. Encrypt backups at rest and in transit. Apply access controls limiting backup access. Store backups separately from production to prevent concurrent compromise. Consider immutable backups to prevent ransomware encryption.

controls.name: Establish and Maintain an Isolated Instance of Recovery Data
controls.description: Maintain isolated backup copies

article.section_name: Establish and Maintain an Isolated Instance of Recovery Data
article.full_text: Establish and maintain an isolated instance of recovery data. Example implementations include version controlling backup destinations through offline, cloud, or off-site systems or services.
article.guidance: Isolated backups protect against ransomware and malicious insiders. Air-gapped, offline, or cloud backups prevent simultaneous compromise. Implement network segmentation for backup infrastructure. Consider write-once-read-many (WORM) storage. Geographic separation protects against local disasters.

controls.name: Test Data Recovery
controls.description: Test data recovery procedures

article.full_text: Test backup recovery quarterly, or more frequently, for a sampling of in-scope enterprise assets.
article.guidance: Untested backups may fail when needed. Regular testing validates backup integrity and recovery procedures. Test full and partial recovery scenarios. Document recovery times to verify RTO/RPO. Include testing in disaster recovery exercises. Rotate tested systems to provide comprehensive coverage.

controls.name: Ensure Network Infrastructure is Up-to-Date
controls.description: Keep network infrastructure current and supported

article.full_text: Ensure network infrastructure is kept up-to-date. Example implementations include running the latest stable release of software and/or using currently supported network-as-a-service (NaaS) offerings. Review software versions monthly, or more frequently.
article.guidance: Network devices are critical infrastructure requiring current software. Outdated firmware contains vulnerabilities. Maintain inventory of network devices with software versions. Plan upgrades before end-of-support. Test updates in non-production before deploying. Subscribe to vendor security advisories.

controls.name: Establish and Maintain a Secure Network Architecture
controls.description: Design and maintain secure network architecture

article.section_name: Establish and Maintain a Secure Network Architecture
article.full_text: Establish and maintain a secure network architecture. A secure network architecture must address segmentation, least privilege, and availability, at a minimum.
article.guidance: Network architecture should implement defense in depth. Segment networks by security zone (DMZ, internal, management). Apply least privilege to network flows. Use VLANs, firewalls, and micro-segmentation. Document architecture with network diagrams. Review architecture when adding new services or systems.

controls.name: Securely Manage Network Infrastructure
controls.description: Implement secure management of network devices

article.full_text: Securely manage network infrastructure. Example implementations include version-controlled-infrastructure-as-code, and the use of secure network protocols, such as SSH and HTTPS. Do not use insecure management protocols, such as Telnet (Teletype Network) and HTTP, unless operationally essential.
article.guidance: Insecure protocols transmit credentials in clear text. Use SSH, HTTPS, SNMPv3 for device management. Separate management network from production. Restrict management access by source IP. Use jump hosts for administrative access. Implement multi-factor authentication for network device access.

controls.name: Establish and Maintain Architecture Diagram(s)
controls.description: Document network architecture

article.full_text: Establish and maintain architecture diagram(s) and/or other network system documentation. Review and update documentation annually, or when significant enterprise changes occur that could impact this Safeguard.
article.guidance: Network diagrams are essential for understanding security posture, troubleshooting, and planning. Document physical and logical topology, security zones, trust boundaries, and data flows. Include IP addressing, device inventory, and security controls. Use automated tools to maintain accuracy.

controls.name: Centralize Network Authentication, Authorization, and Auditing
controls.description: Centralize AAA for network devices

article.section_name: Centralize Network Authentication, Authorization, and Auditing
article.full_text: Centralize network authentication, authorization, and auditing (AAA) for all network devices.
article.guidance: Centralized AAA (RADIUS, TACACS+) simplifies credential management and provides consistent auditing. Eliminates shared local accounts on devices. Supports role-based access control. Provides audit trail of administrative actions. Implement redundant AAA servers for availability.

controls.name: Use of Secure Network Management and Communication Protocols
controls.description: Use secure protocols for network management

article.section_name: Use of Secure Network Management and Communication Protocols
article.full_text: Use secure network management and communication protocols (e.g., 802.1X, Wi-Fi Protected Access 2 (WPA2) Enterprise or WPA3).
article.guidance: Weak wireless security allows unauthorized access. WPA3 provides strongest protection; WPA2-Enterprise is minimum. Disable WEP and WPA-Personal. Use 802.1X for wired and wireless authentication. Implement certificate-based authentication where possible. Regularly rotate pre-shared keys if used.

controls.name: Ensure Remote Devices Utilize a VPN
controls.description: Require VPN for remote access

article.section_name: Ensure Remote Devices Utilize a VPN
article.full_text: Require users to authenticate to enterprise-managed VPN and authentication services prior to accessing enterprise resources on end-user devices.
article.guidance: VPN protects data in transit and extends network security to remote users. Implement strong VPN protocols (IPsec, SSL/TLS). Require multi-factor authentication for VPN access. Consider split-tunneling risks. Modern alternatives include zero trust network access (ZTNA).

controls.name: Establish and Maintain Dedicated Computing Resources
controls.description: Use dedicated resources for high-risk activities

article.section_name: Establish and Maintain Dedicated Computing Resources
article.full_text: Establish and maintain dedicated computing resources, either physically or logically separated, for all administrative tasks or tasks requiring administrative access. The dedicated computing resources need to be segmented from the enterprise's primary network through either physical or logical means.
article.guidance: Dedicated administrative workstations reduce compromise risk. Privileged Access Workstations (PAWs) separate high-privilege activities. Jump hosts provide controlled access. Browser isolation protects against web-based attacks. Implement strict access controls and monitoring for admin systems.

controls.name: Centralize Security Event Alerting
controls.description: Centralize security event alerting and analysis

article.full_text: Centralize security event alerting across enterprise assets for log correlation and analysis. Best practice implementation requires the use of a SIEM, which includes vendor-defined event correlation alerts. A log analytics platform configured with security-relevant correlation alerts also satisfies this Safeguard.
article.guidance: SIEM enables detection of complex attack patterns across multiple systems. Aggregate logs from network devices, servers, applications, and endpoints. Develop correlation rules for known attack patterns. Integrate threat intelligence. Configure alerts for suspicious activities. Tune to reduce false positives.

controls.name: Deploy a Host-Based Intrusion Detection Solution
controls.description: Deploy HIDS on enterprise assets

article.section_name: Deploy a Host-Based Intrusion Detection Solution
article.full_text: Deploy a host-based intrusion detection solution on enterprise assets, where appropriate and/or supported.
article.guidance: HIDS monitors system calls, file integrity, and log files for suspicious activity. Complements network-based detection. EDR solutions provide advanced HIDS capabilities. Configure alerts for configuration changes, privilege escalation, and unauthorized access attempts. Integrate with SIEM.

controls.name: Deploy a Network Intrusion Detection Solution
controls.description: Deploy NIDS for network monitoring

article.section_name: Deploy a Network Intrusion Detection Solution
article.full_text: Deploy a network intrusion detection solution on enterprise assets, where appropriate. Example implementations include the use of a Network Intrusion Detection System (NIDS) or equivalent cloud service provider (CSP) service.
article.guidance: NIDS analyzes network traffic for attack signatures and anomalies. Deploy sensors at key network locations (perimeter, between security zones). Keep signatures updated. Tune to environment to reduce false positives. Consider network traffic analysis (NTA) for advanced threat detection.

controls.name: Perform Traffic Filtering Between Network Segments
controls.description: Filter traffic between network segments

article.section_name: Perform Traffic Filtering Between Network Segments
article.full_text: Perform traffic filtering between network segments, where appropriate.
article.guidance: Network segmentation limits lateral movement during breaches. Firewalls between segments enforce access policies. Define allowed traffic between zones using least privilege. Monitor inter-segment traffic for anomalies. Micro-segmentation provides granular control. Document firewall rules and review regularly.

controls.name: Manage Access Control for Remote Assets
controls.description: Control remote asset access to internal resources

article.section_name: Manage Access Control for Remote Assets
article.full_text: Manage access control for assets remotely connecting to enterprise resources. Determine amount of access to enterprise resources based on: up-to-date anti-malware software installed, configuration compliance with the enterprise's secure configuration process, and ensuring the operating system and applications are up-to-date.
article.guidance: Network Access Control (NAC) verifies device health before granting access. Check for current patches, anti-malware, and configuration compliance. Quarantine non-compliant devices. Provide remediation guidance. Consider zero trust approach requiring continuous verification.

controls.name: Collect Network Traffic Flow Logs
controls.description: Collect and analyze network flow data

article.full_text: Collect network traffic flow logs and/or network traffic to review and alert upon from network devices.
article.guidance: Network flow logs (NetFlow, sFlow, IPFIX) provide visibility into network communications. Useful for detecting C2 traffic, data exfiltration, and lateral movement. Lightweight compared to full packet capture. Analyze flows for volume anomalies, unusual destinations, and off-hours activity.

controls.name: Deploy a Host-Based Intrusion Prevention Solution
controls.description: Deploy HIPS on enterprise assets

article.section_name: Deploy a Host-Based Intrusion Prevention Solution
article.full_text: Deploy a host-based intrusion prevention solution on enterprise assets, where appropriate and/or supported. Example implementations include use of an Endpoint Detection and Response (EDR) client or host-based IPS agent.
article.guidance: HIPS prevents attacks by blocking malicious activities. EDR solutions provide prevention, detection, and response capabilities. Can prevent exploits, credential theft, and malicious scripts. Requires careful tuning to avoid disrupting legitimate activities. Integrate with threat intelligence.

controls.name: Deploy a Network Intrusion Prevention Solution
controls.description: Deploy NIPS for inline traffic inspection

article.section_name: Deploy a Network Intrusion Prevention Solution
article.full_text: Deploy a network intrusion prevention solution, where appropriate. Example implementations include the use of a Network Intrusion Prevention System (NIPS) or equivalent CSP service.
article.guidance: NIPS blocks attacks in real-time by sitting inline in network path. Can prevent exploits, malware downloads, and C2 communications. Performance impact requires consideration. Keep signatures updated. Tune to balance protection with false positive blocking. Deploy at critical network boundaries.

controls.name: Deploy Port-Level Access Control
controls.description: Implement port-level access control

article.full_text: Deploy port-level access control. Port-level access control utilizes 802.1x, or similar network access control protocols, such as certificates, and may incorporate user and/or device authentication.
article.guidance: 802.1X authenticates devices before granting network access. Prevents unauthorized devices from connecting to network ports. Works with RADIUS/certificate authorities. Can be combined with dynamic VLAN assignment. Consider for both wired and wireless networks. Guest network should be isolated.

controls.name: Perform Application Layer Filtering
controls.description: Filter traffic using application awareness

article.full_text: Perform application layer filtering. Example implementations include a filtering proxy, application layer firewall, or gateway.
article.guidance: Application-layer filtering inspects traffic beyond port/protocol. Next-generation firewalls provide this capability. Can identify applications regardless of port. Enforce application usage policies. Detect and block tunneling and evasion techniques. Provides granular control over application features.

controls.name: Tune Security Event Alerting Thresholds
controls.description: Tune alerting to reduce false positives

article.full_text: Tune security event alerting thresholds monthly, or more frequently.
article.guidance: Excessive false positives cause alert fatigue and missed real threats. Regular tuning improves signal-to-noise ratio. Track alert accuracy metrics. Adjust correlation rules and thresholds. Suppress known benign activities. Document tuning decisions. Balance sensitivity with false positive rate.

controls.name: Establish and Maintain a Security Awareness Program
controls.description: Implement security awareness training program

article.section_name: Establish and Maintain a Security Awareness Program
article.full_text: Establish and maintain a security awareness program. The purpose of a security awareness program is to educate the enterprise's workforce on how to interact with enterprise assets and data in a secure manner. Conduct training at hire and, at a minimum, annually. Review and update content annually, or when significant enterprise changes occur that could impact this Safeguard.
article.guidance: Users are often the weakest link in security. Regular training reduces human-related risks. Cover phishing, password security, physical security, and reporting procedures. Track training completion. Use varied delivery methods (videos, newsletters, posters). Make training relevant to job roles.

controls.name: Train Workforce Members to Recognize Social Engineering Attacks
controls.description: Train users to recognize social engineering

article.section_name: Train Workforce Members to Recognize Social Engineering Attacks
article.full_text: Train workforce members to recognize social engineering attacks, such as phishing, pre-texting, and tailgating.
article.guidance: Social engineering bypasses technical controls. Training should include email phishing, phone vishing, SMS smishing, and physical pretexting. Use simulated phishing campaigns to test and train. Provide clear reporting mechanisms. Reward reporting of suspicious activities. Update training with current attack trends.

controls.name: Train Workforce Members on Authentication Best Practices
controls.description: Train users on authentication security

article.section_name: Train Workforce Members on Authentication Best Practices
article.full_text: Train workforce members on authentication best practices. Example topics include MFA, password composition, and credential management.
article.guidance: Weak authentication practices lead to account compromise. Train on password strength, unique passwords per site, password manager use, MFA benefits, and protecting credentials. Explain common credential theft techniques. Demonstrate secure authentication methods. Emphasize never sharing passwords.

controls.name: Train Workforce on Data Handling Best Practices
controls.description: Train users on secure data handling

article.section_name: Train Workforce on Data Handling Best Practices
article.full_text: Train workforce members on how to identify and properly store, transfer, archive, and destroy sensitive data. This also includes training workforce members on clear screen and desk best practices, such as locking their screen when they step away from their enterprise asset, erasing physical and virtual whiteboards at the end of meetings, and storing data and assets securely.
article.guidance: Improper data handling causes breaches. Train on data classification, encryption requirements, secure transmission methods, and proper disposal. Cover physical security (clean desk, screen locking, document shredding). Address cloud storage and file sharing risks. Emphasize data minimization principles.

controls.name: Train Workforce Members on Causes of Unintentional Data Exposure
controls.description: Train on unintentional data exposure risks

article.section_name: Train Workforce Members on Causes of Unintentional Data Exposure
article.full_text: Train workforce members to be aware of causes for unintentional data exposure. Example topics include mis-delivery of sensitive data, losing a portable end-user device, or publishing data to unintended audiences.
article.guidance: Accidental exposure is common breach cause. Train on risks of: misdirected emails, public cloud storage, lost devices, oversharing on collaboration platforms, and misconfigured permissions. Emphasize verifying recipients before sending. Promote use of DLP tools. Encourage reporting of potential exposures.

controls.name: Train Workforce Members on Recognizing and Reporting Security Incidents
controls.description: Train users on incident recognition and reporting

article.section_name: Train Workforce Members on Recognizing and Reporting Security Incidents
article.full_text: Train workforce members to be able to recognize a potential incident and be able to report such an incident.
article.guidance: Early detection enables rapid response. Train users to recognize signs of compromise (unusual system behavior, unexpected emails, suspicious network activity). Provide clear, simple reporting mechanisms. Ensure non-punitive reporting culture. Acknowledge and reward reporting. Follow up on reports promptly.

controls.name: Train Workforce on How to Identify and Report if Their Enterprise Assets are Missing Security Updates
controls.description: Train users to identify missing security updates

article.section_name: Train Workforce on Identifying Missing Security Updates
article.full_text: Train workforce on how to identify out-of-date software on their enterprise assets, and how to report such findings.
article.guidance: Users can help identify unpatched systems. Train on checking software versions, recognizing update notifications, and understanding update importance.
