Provide reporting channel for outdated software. While automated patching is preferred, user awareness provides additional layer. Explain risks of ignoring updates.

controls.name: Train Workforce on the Dangers of Connecting to and Transmitting Enterprise Data Over Insecure Networks
controls.description: Train on insecure network risks

article.full_text: Train workforce members on the dangers of connecting to, and transmitting enterprise data over, insecure networks for enterprise activities. If the enterprise has remote workers, training must include guidance to ensure that all users securely configure their home network infrastructure.
article.guidance: Public WiFi and untrusted networks pose eavesdropping risks. Train on VPN use before accessing enterprise resources. Explain risks of public WiFi for sensitive activities. Provide guidance on securing home networks (changing default passwords, enabling encryption, updating router firmware). Recommend avoiding public networks for high-sensitivity work.

controls.name: Conduct Role-Specific Security Awareness and Skills Training
controls.description: Provide role-specific security training

article.full_text: Conduct role-specific security awareness and skills training. Example implementations include secure system administration, secure software development, and security product usage.
article.guidance: Different roles require specific security knowledge. Developers need secure coding training. Administrators need secure configuration and privilege management training. Security staff need technical skills training. Tailor content to job responsibilities. Provide hands-on training where appropriate. Consider certifications for critical roles.

controls.name: Establish and Maintain an Inventory of Service Providers
controls.description: Maintain inventory of service providers

article.section_name: Establish and Maintain Service Provider Inventory
article.full_text: Establish and maintain an inventory of service providers. The inventory is to list all known service providers, include classification(s), and designate an enterprise contact for each service provider. Review and update the inventory annually, or when significant enterprise changes occur that could impact this Safeguard.
article.guidance: Third-party risks require visibility into service providers. Inventory should include cloud providers, SaaS vendors, managed services, outsourced functions. Document data access, criticality, and contract details. Classify by risk level. Review regularly as provider relationships change. Track subcontractors/fourth parties.

controls.name: Establish and Maintain a Service Provider Management Policy
controls.description: Create service provider management policy

article.full_text: Establish and maintain a service provider management policy. Ensure the policy addresses the classification, inventory, assessment, monitoring, and decommissioning of service providers. Review and update the policy annually, or when significant enterprise changes occur that could impact this Safeguard.
article.guidance: Formalized policy ensures consistent vendor risk management. Policy should cover vendor selection criteria, due diligence requirements, contract security provisions, ongoing monitoring, and off-boarding. Define roles and responsibilities. Address data protection, audit rights, and incident notification requirements. Align with procurement processes.

controls.name: Classify Service Providers
controls.description: Classify service providers by risk

article.full_text: Classify service providers. Classification consideration may include one or more characteristics, such as data sensitivity, and provider type. Update and review classifications annually, or when significant enterprise changes occur that could impact this Safeguard.
article.guidance: Risk-based classification enables proportionate controls. Consider: data accessed, system criticality, regulatory requirements, and financial impact. High-risk providers require enhanced due diligence and monitoring. Classification drives assessment frequency and control requirements. Document classification criteria.

controls.name: Ensure Service Provider Contracts Include Security Requirements
controls.description: Include security requirements in contracts

article.section_name: Include Security Requirements in Service Provider Contracts
article.full_text: Ensure service provider contracts include security requirements. Example requirements may include minimum security program requirements, security incident and/or data breach notification and response, data encryption requirements, and data disposal commitments. These security requirements must be consistent with the enterprise's service provider management policy. Review service provider contracts annually to ensure contracts are not missing security requirements.
article.guidance: Contracts establish security expectations and remedies. Include: security standards compliance, audit/assessment rights, incident notification timelines, data handling requirements, subcontractor restrictions, insurance requirements, right to terminate for security cause. Review contracts before signing. Engage legal and security teams.

controls.name: Assess Service Providers
controls.description: Assess service provider security controls

article.full_text: Assess service providers consistent with the enterprise's service provider management policy. Assessment scope may vary based on classification(s), and may include review of security program documentation, security capabilities, and security requirements. Assess service providers upon selection and on an annual basis, at a minimum.
article.guidance: Due diligence validates provider security posture. Methods include security questionnaires, SOC reports, certifications (ISO 27001, SOC 2), onsite assessments. Assessment depth should match risk classification. Evaluate controls relevant to data/services provided. Document findings and track remediation. Consider shared assessments to reduce redundancy.

controls.name: Monitor Service Providers
controls.description: Monitor ongoing service provider security

article.full_text: Monitor service providers consistent with the enterprise's service provider management policy. Monitoring may include periodic reassessment of service provider compliance, monitoring service provider release notes, and dark web monitoring.
article.guidance: Continuous monitoring detects provider security degradation. Track security incidents, breaches, and vulnerabilities affecting providers. Monitor for changes in certifications/attestations. Subscribe to provider security bulletins. Use threat intelligence for provider compromise monitoring. Conduct periodic reassessments. Review SLA compliance including security metrics.

controls.name: Securely Decommission Service Providers
controls.description: Securely off-board service providers

article.full_text: Securely decommission service providers. Example considerations include user and service account deactivation, termination of data flows, and secure disposal of enterprise data within service provider systems.
article.guidance: Proper off-boarding prevents unauthorized data access. Checklist should include: revoke provider access, retrieve or destroy enterprise data, terminate network connections, recover physical assets, conduct final audit, document completion. Verify data deletion per contract. Address data in backups. Remove provider from security exceptions.

controls.name: Establish and Maintain a Secure Application Development Process
controls.description: Implement secure development lifecycle

article.full_text: Establish and maintain a secure application development process. In the process, address such items as: secure application design standards, secure coding practices, developer training, vulnerability management, security testing, and security requirements definition.
article.guidance: Security must be integrated throughout SDLC. Adopt secure development framework (OWASP, Microsoft SDL, BSIMM). Define security requirements early. Conduct threat modeling. Implement secure coding standards. Use static and dynamic analysis. Perform security testing before release. Include security gates in CI/CD pipeline.

controls.name: Establish and Maintain a Process to Accept and Address Software Vulnerabilities
controls.description: Implement vulnerability disclosure process

article.section_name: Process to Accept and Address Software Vulnerabilities
article.full_text: Establish and maintain a process to accept and address reports of software vulnerabilities, including providing a means for external entities to report. The process is to include such items as: a vulnerability disclosure policy, a reporting mechanism (e.g., a bug bounty program, a vulnerability submission form, or a monitored email address), and a mechanism for acknowledging receipt of reported vulnerabilities. Review and update documentation annually, or when significant enterprise changes occur that could impact this Safeguard.
article.guidance: External researchers find valuable vulnerabilities. Vulnerability disclosure policy sets expectations for reporters. Provide clear reporting mechanism (security@, bug bounty program). Acknowledge reports promptly. Provide timelines for remediation. Recognize helpful reporters. Consider bug bounty programs. Coordinate disclosure timing. Follow responsible disclosure practices.

controls.name: Perform Root Cause Analysis on Security Vulnerabilities
controls.description: Analyze vulnerability root causes

article.section_name: Perform Root Cause Analysis on Security Vulnerabilities
article.full_text: Perform root cause analysis on security vulnerabilities. When reviewing vulnerabilities, root cause analysis is the task of evaluating underlying issues that create vulnerabilities in code, and allows development teams to move beyond just fixing individual vulnerabilities as they arise.
article.guidance: Root cause analysis prevents vulnerability recurrence. Look beyond individual bugs to systemic issues. Common root causes: inadequate input validation, insecure defaults, missing access controls, cryptographic weaknesses. Use findings to improve secure coding training, standards, and tools. Track vulnerability patterns. Share lessons learned with development teams.

controls.name: Establish and Manage an Inventory of Third-Party Software Components
controls.description: Inventory third-party software components

article.full_text: Establish and manage an updated inventory of third-party components used in development, often referred to as a "bill of materials," as well as components slated for future use. This inventory is to include any risks that each third-party component could pose. Review and update this inventory monthly, or more frequently.
article.guidance: Third-party components introduce supply chain risks. Maintain software bill of materials (SBOM) listing all dependencies. Track component versions, licenses, and known vulnerabilities. Use software composition analysis (SCA) tools. Monitor for newly disclosed vulnerabilities in components. Have process to update or replace vulnerable components. Consider component risk in selection.

controls.name: Use Up-to-Date and Trusted Third-Party Software Components
controls.description: Use current and trusted third-party components

article.section_name: Use Up-to-Date and Trusted Third-Party Components
article.full_text: Use up-to-date and trusted third-party software components. When possible, choose established and proven frameworks and libraries that provide adequate security. Acquire these components from trusted sources or evaluate the software for vulnerabilities before use.
article.guidance: Outdated components contain known vulnerabilities. Keep dependencies current with security patches. Use reputable sources for components (official repositories, verified publishers). Evaluate component security before adoption. Prefer well-maintained projects with active communities. Consider component popularity and maturity. Scan components for vulnerabilities before use.
article.external_references: OWASP Top 10 A06:2021 (Vulnerable and Outdated Components)

controls.name: Establish and Maintain a Severity Rating System and Process for Application Vulnerabilities
controls.description: Rate application vulnerability severity

article.section_name: Severity Rating System for Application Vulnerabilities
article.full_text: Establish and maintain a severity rating system and process for application vulnerabilities that facilitates prioritizing the order in which discovered vulnerabilities are fixed. This process includes setting a minimum level of security acceptability for releasing code or applications. Severity ratings bring a systematic way of triaging vulnerabilities that improves risk management and helps ensure the most critical vulnerabilities are addressed swiftly.
article.guidance: Severity ratings prioritize remediation efforts. Use standardized scoring (CVSS, OWASP Risk Rating). Consider exploitability, impact, and affected systems. Define SLAs for remediation by severity. Establish quality gates for releases (no criticals, limited highs). Risk acceptance should require executive approval. Track remediation metrics. Automate severity assignment where possible.

controls.name: Use Standard Hardening Configuration Templates for Application Infrastructure
controls.description: Harden application infrastructure

article.section_name: Standard Hardening Configuration for Application Infrastructure
article.full_text: Use standard, industry-recommended hardening configuration templates for application infrastructure components. This includes underlying servers, databases, and web servers, and applies to cloud containers, Platform as a Service (PaaS) components, or system images used by Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) components. Do not allow in-house developed software to weaken configuration hardening.
article.guidance: Hardened infrastructure reduces attack surface. Use CIS Benchmarks, DISA STIGs, or vendor hardening guides. Apply principle of least functionality—disable unnecessary services and features. Harden web servers, application servers, and databases. Implement security headers. Configure TLS properly. Use infrastructure as code for consistent deployment. Scan for configuration issues.

controls.name: Separate Production and Non-Production Systems
controls.description: Segregate production and non-production environments

article.full_text: Maintain separate environments for production and non-production systems. Designers and developers should not have unmonitored access to production systems.
article.guidance: Production/non-production separation prevents accidental production changes and protects production data. Use separate networks, accounts, and credentials. Restrict developer access to production. Sanitize production data before use in non-production. Implement change control between environments. Monitor production access. Use production-like non-production environments for realistic testing.

controls.name: Train Developers in Application Security Concepts and Secure Coding
controls.description: Provide secure coding training to developers

article.full_text: Ensure that all software development personnel receive training in writing secure code for their specific development environment and responsibilities. Training can include general security principles and application security standard practices. Conduct training at least annually and update it regularly with new security techniques and best practices.
article.guidance: Developer knowledge is critical for secure applications. Training should cover OWASP Top 10, secure coding for specific languages/frameworks, common vulnerability types, and secure design principles. Use hands-on labs and code examples. Provide reference materials and secure coding checklists. Consider security champions program. Make training relevant to technologies used.

controls.name: Apply Secure Design Principles in Application Architectures
controls.description: Use secure design principles

article.full_text: Apply secure design principles in application architectures. Secure design principles include the concept of least privilege and enforcing mediation to validate every operation that the user makes, promoting the concept of "never trust user input." Examples include ensuring that explicit error checking is performed and documented for all input, including for size, data type, and acceptable ranges or formats. Secure design also means minimizing the application infrastructure attack surface, such as turning off unprotected ports and services, removing unnecessary programs and files, and renaming or removing default accounts.
article.guidance: Secure design prevents entire vulnerability classes. Apply principles: least privilege, defense in depth, fail securely, separation of duties, economy of mechanism, complete mediation, open design, least common mechanism. Never trust user input—validate all input. Use threat modeling during design. Design for security from the start rather than adding it later. Document security design decisions.
article.external_references: OWASP ASVS, Saltzer and Schroeder Security Principles

controls.name: Leverage Vetted Modules or Services for Application Security Components
controls.description: Use proven security libraries

article.full_text: Leverage vetted modules or services for application security components, such as identity management, encryption, and auditing and logging. Using platform features in critical security functions will reduce developers' workload and minimize the likelihood of design or implementation errors. Modern operating systems provide effective mechanisms for identification, authentication, and authorization and make those mechanisms available to applications. Use only standardized, currently accepted, and extensively reviewed encryption algorithms. Operating systems also provide mechanisms to create and maintain secure audit logs.
article.guidance: Don't roll your own crypto or authentication. Use established, vetted libraries for security functions. Leverage platform security features (OS authentication, cryptographic APIs). Use OAuth/OIDC for authorization, bcrypt/Argon2 for password hashing, TLS for encryption. Proven libraries have been extensively tested and reviewed. Custom security code often contains flaws.

controls.name: Implement Code-Level Security Checks
controls.description: Perform security checks during development

article.full_text: Apply static and dynamic analysis tools to verify that secure coding practices are being followed and to identify potential software security weaknesses. Security weaknesses found during the code review are to be tracked and addressed in a timely manner. Static and dynamic analysis tools must be updated regularly for accurate detection of coding weaknesses.
article.guidance: Automated code analysis finds vulnerabilities early. Static analysis (SAST) scans source code without execution. Dynamic analysis (DAST) tests running applications. Interactive analysis (IAST) combines both approaches. Integrate into CI/CD pipeline. Set quality gates based on findings. Tune tools to reduce false positives. Combine with manual code review. Track and remediate findings.
article.external_references: OWASP Code Review Guide, NIST SP 800-218

controls.name: Conduct Application Penetration Testing
controls.description: Test applications for security vulnerabilities

article.full_text: Conduct penetration testing on web-based and other application software prior to release, using techniques that exploit common vulnerabilities, including but not limited to authorization and authentication, and input validation. Applications that consume third-party components or APIs should be tested for vulnerabilities within the integrated application.
article.guidance: Penetration testing validates security in realistic attack scenarios. Test before initial release and after significant changes. Include OWASP Top 10 vulnerabilities. Test authentication, authorization, input validation, session management. Test APIs and integrations. Use both automated scanning and manual testing. Remediate findings before release. Consider bug bounty programs for ongoing testing.

controls.name: Conduct Threat Modeling
controls.description: Perform threat modeling for applications

article.full_text: Conduct threat modeling for high-value, high-risk, or mission-critical applications. This helps identify and address potential security design flaws within an application early in the development lifecycle. Conduct threat modeling every three years at a minimum, or when a significant change is made to an application or application hosting infrastructure. When modeling, consider technologies, applications, services, and threat actors that may or may not be currently supported or known. Threat modeling can inform security requirements for technologies, applications, and services that may also have implications on how to securely configure such technologies, applications, and services.
article.guidance: Threat modeling identifies security risks during design. Use structured approach (STRIDE, PASTA, Attack Trees). Document assets, entry points, trust boundaries, and data flows. Identify threats for each component. Prioritize threats by risk. Define mitigations. Update models as architecture changes. Engage developers, architects, and security team. Document findings and track mitigation implementation.
article.external_references: OWASP Threat Modeling, Microsoft Threat Modeling Tool

controls.name: Perform a Skills Gap Analysis
controls.description: Assess incident response capability gaps

article.full_text: Perform a skills gap analysis to understand the roles and skills required to support security operations, and use gap analysis to determine training requirements.
article.guidance: Understanding capability gaps enables targeted improvement. Assess current incident response capabilities against required skills. Identify gaps in people, process, and technology. Consider incident types likely to affect organization. Plan training, hiring, or outsourcing to address gaps. Review annually as threats and technology evolve. Document findings and improvement plans.

controls.name: Assign Job Titles and Duties for Incident Response
controls.description: Define incident response roles and responsibilities

article.full_text: Assign job titles and duties for incident response, and ensure a role includes an owner, with authority and responsibility to manage incidents.
article.guidance: Clear roles prevent confusion during incidents. Define: incident manager, technical leads, communications, legal, HR roles. Document responsibilities and authority. Establish escalation paths. Designate primary and backup for each role. Ensure 24/7 coverage for critical roles. Provide role-specific training. Document contact information. Include executives in appropriate roles.

controls.name: Establish and Maintain Contact Information for Reporting Security Incidents
controls.description: Maintain incident reporting contact information

article.full_text: Establish and maintain contact information for reporting security incidents. Verify contacts annually to ensure that information is up-to-date. Contact information should include a means of accessing the incident response team at any time of day.
article.guidance: Accessible reporting enables rapid response. Provide multiple reporting channels (email, phone, portal, chat). Make contact information easy to find. Ensure 24/7 availability for critical systems. Include contacts for external parties (law enforcement, regulators, vendors). Test contact methods regularly. Update emergency contact lists. Communicate reporting procedures to workforce.

controls.name: Establish and Maintain an Incident Response Process
controls.description: Document incident response procedures

article.full_text: Establish and maintain an incident response process that addresses roles and responsibilities, compliance requirements, and a communication plan. Review annually, or when significant enterprise changes occur that could impact this Safeguard.
article.guidance: Documented process ensures consistent, effective response. Address: detection, analysis, containment, eradication, recovery, post-incident activity. Define severity classification and escalation. Include communication templates and procedures. Address evidence handling and chain of custody. Document legal and regulatory notification requirements. Integrate with business continuity. Test process through exercises.

controls.name: Assign Key Roles and Responsibilities
controls.description: Designate incident response team members

article.full_text: Assign key roles and responsibilities for incident response, including staff from IT, legal, HR, and other business functions. Review and update roles annually, or when significant enterprise changes occur that could impact this Safeguard.
article.guidance: Cross-functional team addresses all incident aspects. Include: technical analysis (IT/security), legal (counsel), communications (PR), human resources (insider threats), business units (impact assessment), management (decision authority). Define when to engage each role. Document contact information. Conduct team building activities. Ensure understanding of responsibilities.

controls.name: Define Mechanisms for Communicating During Incident Response
controls.description: Establish incident communication methods

article.full_text: Determine which primary and secondary communication mechanisms would be used to communicate during an incident. Mechanisms can include phone calls, emails, or letters. Keep in mind that certain mechanisms, such as emails, can be affected during a security incident.
article.guidance: Reliable communication is critical during incidents. Primary and backup channels needed (phone, secure messaging, out-of-band email). Consider that enterprise systems may be compromised or unavailable. Establish communication protocols (conference bridges, war rooms). Prepare communication templates. Define information sharing limitations. Test communication channels. Include external communication methods (customers, media, regulators).

controls.name: Conduct Routine Incident Response Exercises
controls.description: Practice incident response procedures

article.full_text: Plan and conduct routine incident response exercises, including tabletop exercises, technical exercises, and red team/blue team exercises. Exercises should involve relevant stakeholders, including IT, HR, legal, and communications.
article.guidance: Exercises test and improve incident response capabilities. Conduct tabletop exercises to walk through scenarios. Technical exercises test specific tools/procedures. Red team/blue team exercises simulate real attacks. Vary scenarios (malware, data breach, DDoS, insider threat). Include realistic complications. Document lessons learned. Update procedures based on findings. Conduct at least annually.
article.external_references: NIST SP 800-61, CISA tabletop exercise packages

controls.name: Conduct Post-Incident Reviews
controls.description: Review and learn from incidents

article.full_text: Conduct post-incident reviews. Post-incident reviews help ensure that lessons learned are communicated to the right people to improve the enterprise's response to future incidents.
article.guidance: Learning from incidents prevents recurrence. Conduct review shortly after incident closure while details are fresh. Include all response team members. Document: timeline, root cause, what went well, what needs improvement, action items. Focus on process improvement, not blame. Share lessons learned appropriately. Track action item completion. Update procedures and training based on findings.

controls.name: Establish and Maintain Security Incident Thresholds
controls.description: Define incident severity thresholds

article.full_text: Establish and maintain security incident thresholds, including, at a minimum, differentiating between an incident and an event. Examples can include: abnormal activity, security vulnerability, security weakness, data breach, privacy incident, etc. Review annually, or when significant enterprise changes occur that could impact this Safeguard.
article.guidance: Clear thresholds enable appropriate response. Define incident severity levels (low, medium, high, critical) with specific criteria. Distinguish events from incidents requiring formal response. Consider factors: data sensitivity, system criticality, number of affected users, regulatory implications. Define escalation triggers. Document notification requirements by severity. Use consistent classification. Review and adjust thresholds based on experience.

controls.name: Establish and Maintain a Penetration Testing Program
controls.description: Create formalized penetration testing program

article.full_text: Establish and maintain a penetration testing program appropriate to the size, complexity, and maturity of the enterprise. Penetration testing program characteristics include: scope, such as network, web application, API, hosted services, and physical premise controls; frequency; limitations, such as acceptable hours, and excluded attack types; threat model; drive-by compromise prevention; and remediation workflow.
article.guidance: Penetration testing validates security controls under adversarial conditions. Define scope (external, internal, applications, physical, social). Determine frequency based on risk (annually minimum for IG2, more frequent for high-risk systems). Use qualified testers (internal team or external firm). Follow rules of engagement. Establish reporting and remediation processes. Track findings to closure. Consider continuous testing approaches.
article.external_references: PTES, OWASP Testing Guide, NIST SP 800-115

controls.name: Perform Periodic External Penetration Tests
controls.description: Conduct external penetration tests

article.full_text: Perform periodic external penetration tests based on program requirements, no less than annually. External penetration testing must include enterprise and environmental reconnaissance to detect exploitable information. Penetration testing requires specialized skills and experience and must be conducted through a qualified party. The testing may be clear box or opaque box.
article.guidance: External testing simulates attacker perspective. Test internet-facing systems (websites, VPN, email, DNS). Include reconnaissance phase. Test for OWASP Top 10 and common vulnerabilities. Attempt to gain unauthorized access. Document all findings. Provide detailed report with remediation guidance. Retest after remediation. Consider both authenticated and unauthenticated testing. Use qualified, experienced testers.

controls.name: Remediate Penetration Test Findings
controls.description: Fix vulnerabilities discovered during penetration tests

article.full_text: Remediate penetration test findings based on the enterprise's policy for remediation scope and prioritization.
article.guidance: Testing is only valuable if findings are addressed. Prioritize remediation by severity and exploitability. Set remediation timelines (critical: 30 days, high: 60 days, etc.). Track findings to closure. Verify remediation effectiveness through retesting. Document risk acceptance for findings that cannot be immediately remediated. Report remediation status to management. Use findings to improve security program.

controls.name: Validate Security Measures
controls.description: Validate that security controls function as intended

article.full_text: Validate security measures after each penetration test. If deemed necessary, modify the enterprise's security plan, incident response plan, and penetration testing program.
article.guidance: Validation ensures controls work as designed. Review test findings against security architecture and controls. Identify control gaps or failures. Assess whether controls detected/prevented test activities. Update security measures based on findings. Modify security policies and standards. Enhance detection capabilities. Improve incident response based on lessons learned. Update threat model with observed attack techniques.

controls.name: Perform Periodic Internal Penetration Tests
controls.description: Conduct internal penetration tests

article.full_text: Perform periodic internal penetration tests based on program requirements, no less than annually. The testing may be clear box or opaque box.
article.guidance: Internal testing simulates insider threat or post-compromise scenario. Test from inside network perimeter. Attempt lateral movement and privilege escalation. Test segmentation effectiveness. Target high-value systems. Assess detective controls. Document paths to critical assets. Internal tests should simulate both malicious insider and compromised account scenarios. Use qualified testers. Remediate findings.
